abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Small Industries
            Project for Pakistan was satisfactory. The main objectives
            of the project were achieved. The sub loan components
            provided financial assistance to more SSI (Small Scale
            Industries) units than expected at appraisal and established
            the basis for developing a sound SSI credit delivery system.
            Implementation of the technical assistance components were
            completed on schedule despite start-up delays. However,
            institution building objectives implicit in the
            implementation of these components was weak due to problems
            with some counterpart staff and advisors. Several lessons
            can be learned from this project. First, expanding outlets
            for SSI financing from a single intermediary to five
            nationalized commercial banks has improved SSI's access
            to credit. Second, project-based appraisal methodology
            should be complemented with traditional procedures of
            commercial banks. Third, expansion of SSI financing occurred
            mainly because banks were provided with funds of matching
            maturities and given sufficient spreads to cover costs.
            Fourth, it is more efficient to start with a more
            centralized loan processing system rather than requiring
            decentralization from the start. Fifth, implementation of
            technical assistance components is usually much slower than
            the sub loan component. Lastly, technical assistance
            components achieved success by focusing on potential
            clientele, involving private sector associations, and
            defining specific objectives.
